urn:contentItem:6F8K-D8B3-RTBS-B2FR-00000-00Studies from University of Hertfordshire Yield New Data on Machine Learning (Machine Learning and Deep Learning-Based Multi-Attribute Physical-Layer Authentication for Spoofing Detection in LoRaWAN)2025-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGStudies from University of Hertfordshire Yield New Data on Machine Learning (Machine Learning and Deep Learning-Based Multi-Attribute Physical-Layer Authentication for Spoofing Detection in LoRaWAN)


2025 MAR 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Telecommunications Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in artificial intelligence. According to news reporting out of Hatfield, United Kingdom, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "The use of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) in critical applications such as environmental monitoring, smart agriculture, and industrial automation has created significant security concerns, particularly due to the broadcasting nature of wireless communication."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from University of Hertfordshire: "The absence of physical-layer authentication mechanisms exposes these networks to threats like spoofing, compromising data authenticity. This paper introduces a multi-attribute physical layer authentication (PLA) scheme to enhance WSN security by using physical attributes such as received signal strength indicator (RSSI), battery level (BL), and altitude. The LoRaWAN join procedure, a key risk due to plain text transmission without encryption during initial communication, is addressed in this study. To evaluate the proposed approach, a partially synthesized dataset was developed. Real-world RSSI values were sourced from the LoRa at the Edge Dataset, while BL and altitude columns were added to simulate realistic sensor behavior in a forest fire detection scenario. Machine learning (ML) models, including Logistic Regression (LR), Random Forest (RF), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), were compared with deep learning (DL) models, such as Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The results showed that RF achieved the highest accuracy among machine learning models, while MLP and CNN delivered competitive performance with higher resource demands."
For more information on this research see: Machine Learning and Deep Learning-Based Multi-Attribute Physical-Layer Authentication for Spoofing Detection in LoRaWAN. Future Internet, 2025,17(2):68. (Future Internet - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/futureinternet/). The publisher for Future Internet is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fi17020068.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Azita Pourghasem, Cybersecurity and Computing Systems Research Group, Department of Computer Science, University of Hertfordshire, Hatfield AL10 9AB, United Kingdom. Additional authors for this research include Raimund Kirner, Athanasios Tsokanos, Iosif Mporas, Alexios Mylonas.
Keywords for this news article include: University of Hertfordshire, Hatfield, United Kingdom, Europe, Cybersecurity, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning.

urn:contentItem:6FDC-CPP3-RRYJ-Y15C-00000-00Wildfires force evacuations in Carolinas; forest ablaze in NJ2025-03-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Wildfires force evacuations in Carolinas; forest ablaze in NJThe Associated Press

Wildfires forced a mandatory evacuation Sunday in a North Carolina county still recovering from Hurricane Helene, and South Carolina's governor declared an emergency in response to a growing wildfire in that state. Hundreds of miles north, the New Jersey Forest Fire Service was battling a blaze in the Wharton State Forest. The North Carolina Department of Public Safety announced a mandatory evacuation starting at 8:20 p.m. Saturday for parts of Polk County in western North Carolina about 80 miles (129 kilometers) west of Charlotte.

"Visibility in area will be reduced and roads/evacuation routes can become blocked; if you do not leave now, you could be trapped, injured, or killed," the agency said in a social media post. A shelter had been established in Columbus, North Carolina. There were three active fires in Polk County, with one spanning 1.9 square miles (5 square kilometers) and another spread over 2.8 square miles (7.3 square kilometers) with no containment by Sunday afternoon. County spokesperson Kellie Cannon said one home was lost to the larger of the two fires. A third fire that had burned about 199 acres (81 hectares) with 50% containment had destroyed three homes. And earlier evacuation order associated with that fire had been lifted, Cannon said. The North Carolina Forest Service's online wildfire public viewer indicated active fires Sunday in Burke County and in Stokes County on the northern border with Virginia. In South Carolina, Gov. Henry McMaster declared a state of emergency Saturday as emergency crews in Pickens County fought the Table Rock Fire in the Blue Ridge Mountains. "The State of Emergency allows us to mobilize resources quickly and ensure our firefighters have the support they need," McMaster said in a statement that reinforced a statewide outdoor burning ban issued Friday by the South Carolina Forestry Commission. Local fire officials called for voluntary evacuations Saturday of some residents near Table Rock Mountain.

urn:contentItem:6DSR-8VN3-RYBV-N38B-00000-00New Forestry Research from Forest Research Institute Discussed (Fuel models for forest soil cover plant)2024-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - FORESTRYNew Forestry Research from Forest Research Institute Discussed (Fuel models for forest soil cover plant)


2024 DEC 31 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- Data detailed on forestry have been presented. According to news originating from Raszyn, Poland, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "This study presents the development and application of forest fuel models to predict fire behaviour in different forest habitats, focusing on biomass distribution, moisture variability and the calorific value of soil cover components."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Forest Research Institute: "On analysing forest fire data from 2007 to 2013, we identified high-risk habitats, especially in younger stands and in stands dominated by Scots pine. The variability of moisture in the different soil cover components, including litter and deadwood, was statistically analysed; it revealed significant dependencies on litter moisture and rain-free intervals. These dependencies allowed the creation of equations to accurately predict fuel load and moisture content based on stand age, habitat type and environmental conditions. Using the calorific value measurements with an average calorific value of 18,920 kJ/kg for dry soil cover materials, fuel models were developed to estimate the potential intensity of fires. The models categorise the biomass into decayed, dead and live components and take into account key variables such as bulk density and moisture content that influence fire spread. Data-driven categorisation enables fire risk assessments at the compartment level, which increases accuracy compared to more comprehensive district-level assessments."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Applications of fuel models include mapping the spatial distribution of biomass by fuel type, creating fire hazard maps and optimising firefighting infrastructure. These models support planning and operations by enabling forest managers to visualise high-risk areas and predict fire behaviour based on real-time meteorological data. The models are a critical step towards a more effective firefighting system that provides fine-grained, actionable insights into fire risk at the local level."
For more information on this research see: Fuel models for forest soil cover plant. Folia Forestalia Polonica, 2024,66(4). (Folia Forestalia Polonica - http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/ffp). The publisher for Folia Forestalia Polonica is Walter de Gruyter GmbH.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.2478/ffp-2024-0025.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Lukasz Tyburski, Forest Research Institute, Laboratory of Forest Fire Protection, Sekocin Stary, Braci Lesnej 3, Raszyn, Poland. Additional authors for this research include Damian Czubak, Ryszard Szczygiel, Miroslaw Kwiatkowski.
Keywords for this news article include: Forest Research Institute, Raszyn, Poland, , Agriculture, Forestry.

urn:contentItem:6DWX-H0N3-RXDR-N3K0-00000-00UPDATE ON CANADA'S RESPONSE TO THE WILDFIRES IN CALIFORNIA2025-01-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisUPDATE ON CANADA'S RESPONSE TO THE WILDFIRES IN CALIFORNIAStates News ServiceOTTAWA, Ontario

The following information was released by the Government of Canada:

Canada continues to provide support to the United States as they battle the devastating wildfires in southern California.

On January 13, the province of Alberta sent a trained and experienced crew of 40 Type 1 wildland firefighters and two support staff. Additional Type 1 firefighters, Incident Command personnel, and qualified support staff will be ready to go if requested. Alberta is also preparing water bombers and contracted night vision helicopters to be ready if needed.

This past Saturday, the province of British Columbia sent a team of senior technical staff to fill specialized incident command system functions. This is part of a long-standing bilateral relationship with CAL Fire and based on their request for support. B.C. is also sending a crew of Type 1 firefighters, through a U.S. National Interagency Coordination Center (NICC) and Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre (CIFFC) request for support.

In addition to the two CL-415 water bombers sent in August 2024 to Los Angeles, the province of Quebec is deploying two other CL-415 water bombers to support firefighting efforts in California. Quebec also has 60 Type 1 wildland firefighters available and on standby for deployment.

The Government of Canada continues to coordinate efforts with Provinces and Territories to line up all available resources to help the people of California. Canadian agencies continue to work closely with the United States Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), the NICC, the California Governor's Office of Emergency Services and the City of Los Angeles to respond to requests and determine how best to assist in the response and recovery efforts.

Provinces in Canada continue to assess how they can help California's response; to date the following is also being mobilized, if requested by the United States:

Ontario: Is preparing to deploy two CL-415 waterbombers to Abbotsford, BC on January 14, weather permitting, to help with fire suppression in California, if requested. Forest fire suppression equipment and an Incident Management Team are also on standby for deployment within 24-48 hours if requested.

Saskatchewan: Has offered a wildland fire team and wildfire equipment.

Atlantic region (New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island): Assembled a 20 person Type 1 firefighter crew ready to deploy if requested, and is investigating the availability of additional resources.

In addition to the supports listed above, specific commitments being offered include:

The Canadian Armed Forces remains on standby with air transport capabilities to deploy provincial/civilian firefighting personnel and equipment.

The Canadian Coast Guard continues to work with partners to offer support and to explore available resources, such as Incident Command resources that could be deployed to assist the response, if requested.

CIFFC and Natural Resources Canada are working closely with the NICC and provincial/territorial authorities to continue building on our response by identifying more resources that can be deployed to support the response, including aircraft.

Parks Canada has offered wildland firefighting resources, including a Type 1 wildfire personnel, incident command personnel, structural protection equipment, and other firefighting equipment.

Transport Canada is ready to provide one National Aerial Surveillance Program (NASP) aircraft for fire mapping and hot spot detections and also prepared to deploy a Canadian liaison officer in any fire operational headquarters should the NASP aircraft be deployed.

urn:contentItem:6F23-K693-RRVB-T2XH-00000-00SES AI Reportd Significant Purchase Order From Data Blanket2025-02-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisSES AI Reportd Significant Purchase Order From Data Blanket

SES AI Corp., a company focusing on the development and manufacturing of AI-enhanced high-performance Li-Metal and Li-ion batteries, reported that it has received a significant purchase order from Data Blanket, a global provider of AI-driven drones.

According to a release, the purchase order is for high energy density and high-power density AI-enhanced Li-Metal and Li-ion batteries. These batteries will support the use of AI-driven drones in forest fire management and border patrol. SES AI delivered initial shipments of the AI-enhanced batteries in December 2024 and expects to deliver the balance by mid-2025.

SES AI Founder and CEO Qichao Hu commented, "These AI-driven drones from Data Blanket help provide rapid, safe, and firsthand data and images to firefighters and help them do their jobs and save lives. We are incredibly proud to be supplying our batteries to Data Blanket on this mission. The higher energy density and power that our AI- enhanced batteries can provide keep these drones in the air longer than conventional Li-ion batteries."

Data Blanket CEO Omer Bar-Yohay added, "The technology SES has brought to maturity, from Li-Metal to AI-enabled management and safety systems, is an enabling combination for us at Data Blanket. It allows longer operations and the safe deployment of batteries in harsh environments. We expect to grow this cooperation and include SES systems across our growing product line."

More information and complete details:

www.ses.ai

urn:contentItem:6CY8-BFD1-JBSP-132M-00000-00Researchers at Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology Have Published New Data on Algorithms (Enhanced forest fire evacuation planning using real-time sensor and GPS algorithm)2024-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisALGORITHMSResearchers at Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology Have Published New Data on Algorithms (Enhanced forest fire evacuation planning using real-time sensor and GPS algorithm)


2024 SEP 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on algorithms. According to news reporting out of Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires are the source of countless fatalities and extreme economic repercussions."


Financial supporters for this research include King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Through Researchers Supporting Project; National Research Foundation of Korea (Nrf) Grant Funded By The Korean Government.
The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology: "The safe evacuation of residents of an area affected by forest fires is the highest priority of local authorities, and finding the most optimal course of action has been a primary research focus for years. Previous studies over several decades have attempted to find an optimal solution using the applications of bug navigation systems, road network reconfiguration, graph traversals, swarm optimization, etc. The author, with the motivation to prevent human casualties at the time of such calamity, presents a novel study which solves the problem in nearly linear time computation, surpassing the performance standards of previous research, and accommodates the unpredictability of the spread of forest fires."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This includes a proposal of an algorithm which builds upon the application of Spielman and Teng's Electrical Circuit Approach to solve for maximum flow in a network and implements this with real-time sensor and Global Positioning System input."
For more information on this research see: Enhanced forest fire evacuation planning using real-time sensor and GPS algorithm. Scientific Reports, 2024,14(1):1-12. (Scientific Reports - http://www.nature.com/srep/index.html). The publisher for Scientific Reports is Nature Portfolio.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-024-71052-8.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Vishal Sharma, Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University. Additional authors for this research include Deepali Nagpal, Suhasini Monga, Ahmad Almogren, Durgesh Srivastava, Ayman Altameem, Jaeyoung Choi.
Keywords for this news article include: Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Algorithms.

urn:contentItem:6DTC-6753-S75C-S4WS-00000-00Researchers from North Arizona University Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Artificial Intelligence (Efficient Artificial Intelligence With Novel Matrix Transformations and Homomorphic Encryption)2025-01-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCEResearchers from North Arizona University Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Artificial Intelligence (Efficient Artificial Intelligence With Novel Matrix Transformations and Homomorphic Encryption)


2025 JAN 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- Fresh data on Artificial Intelligence are presented in a new report. According to news reporting from Flagstaff, Arizona, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "This paper addresses the challenges of data privacy and computational efficiency in artificial intelligence (AI) models by proposing a novel hybrid model that combines homomorphic encryption (HE) with AI to enhance security while maintaining learning accuracy. The novelty of our model lies in the introduction of a new matrix transformation technique that ensures compatibility with both HE algorithms and AI model weight matrices, significantly improving computational efficiency."


Financial support for this research came from National Science Foundation (NSF).
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from North Arizona University, "Furthermore, we present a first-of-its-kind mathematical proof of convergence for integrating HE into AI models using the adaptive moment estimation optimization algorithm. The effectiveness and practicality of our approach for training on encrypted data are showcased through comprehensive evaluations of well-known datasets for air pollution forecasting and forest fire detection. These successful results demonstrate high model performance, with nearly 1 R-squared for air pollution forecasting and 99% accuracy for forest fire detection. Additionally, our approach achieves a reduction of up to 90% in data storage and a tenfold increase in speed compared to models that do not use the matrix transformation method."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Our primary contribution lies in enhancing the security, efficiency, and dependability of AI models, particularly when dealing with sensitive data."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Efficient Artificial Intelligence With Novel Matrix Transformations and Homomorphic Encryption. Ieee Journal On Emerging and Selected Topics In Circuits and Systems, 2024;14(4):717-728. Ieee Journal On Emerging and Selected Topics In Circuits and Systems can be contacted at: Ieee-inst Electrical Electronics Engineers Inc, 445 Hoes Lane, Piscataway, NJ 08855-4141, USA.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Tuy Tan Nguyen, North Arizona University, Sch Informat Comp & Cyber Syst, Flagstaff, AZ 86011, United States.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1109/JETCAS.2024.3466849. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

March 3rd, 2025 ( Al Jazeera English - Delivered by Newstex )

More than 2,000 firefighters, backed by military helicopters, are battling Japan's biggest forest fire in three decades, as the blaze burns thousands of hectares of land every day.

Officials on Monday said about 4,600 residents remain under evacuation advisories as the fire rages in the northern Iwate region, killing at least one person last week.

The fire, which broke out near the city of Ofunato, follows record low rainfall in the area and last year's hottest summer on record across Japan, as climate change pushes up temperatures worldwide.

'Although it is inevitable that the fire will spread to some extent, we will take all possible measures to ensure there will be no impact on people's homes,' Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said in parliament.

The fire has consumed approximately 5,200 acres (2,100 hectares) of land since it started on Thursday, the country's Fire and Disaster Management Agency (FDMA) said on Monday.

'We are still examining the size of the affected area, but it is the biggest since the 1992 wildfire' in Kushiro, FDMA spokesman Hokkaido told the AFP news agency on Saturday.

Evacuated residents at a shelter in the city of Ofunato, Iwate Prefecture [File: JIJI Press via AFP]

Firefighters from 14 Japanese regions, including units from Tokyo, were tackling the blaze, with 16 helicopters - including from the military - trying to douse the flames.

It is estimated to have damaged 84 buildings by Sunday, although details were still being assessed, the FDMA said.

About 2,000 people have left the area to stay with friends or relatives, while more than 1,200 evacuated to shelters, according to officials.

Footage from Ofunato on national broadcaster NHK showed orange flames close to buildings and white smoke billowing into the air.

While the number of wildfires in Japan has decreased since the 1970s, according to government data, the country still recorded about 1,300 such incidents in 2023, concentrated in the February to April period when the air dries and winds strengthen.

Ofunato saw just 2.5mm (0.1 inches) of rainfall in February - breaking the previous record low for the month of 4.4mm in 1967 and below the usual average of 41mm.

Some types of extreme weather have a well-established link with climate change, such as heatwaves or heavy rainfall. Other phenomena like droughts, snowstorms, tropical storms and forest fires can result from a combination of complex factors.

urn:contentItem:6FDM-GM93-S10P-G22S-00000-00STATEWIDE BURN BAN REMAINS IN EFFECT AS FIRE ACTIVITY INCREASES DURING PERIOD OF CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER2025-03-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisSTATEWIDE BURN BAN REMAINS IN EFFECT AS FIRE ACTIVITY INCREASES DURING PERIOD OF CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER

RALEIGH, N.C., March 22 -- The North Carolina Forest Service issued the following news release:

The N.C. Forest Service is reminding the public that a statewide ban on open burning remains in effect until further notice as most of the state is currently experiencing critical fire weather. A combination of strong winds, low relative humidity and warm temperatures are contributing to extreme fire behavior.

In addition to providing initial attack response for several large and active wildfires across multiple forest service districts, N.C. Forest Service personnel are responding to reports of non-escaped illegal fires while the statewide burn ban is in place. Using outdoor fire during a burn ban is prohibited by law and unnecessarily challenges response capabilities.

Significant fire activity across the state includes the following:

* The Black Cove, Deep Woods and Fish Hook fires continue burning in Polk County. The Black Cove Fire is 1,239 acres in size with no containment. The Deep Woods Fire is 1,102 acres in size with no containment. The Fish Hook Fire is 152 acres and 50% contained. Helene debris and rugged terrain are posing challenges for containment on all three fires.

* Other significant wildfires burning in Western North Carolina are the Old Hwy 16 #1 Fire in Wilkes County, the Iron Circle Fire in Burke County and the Caleb Lane Fire in Caldwell County. The Old Hwy 16 #1 Fire is about 200 acres in size and 50% contained. The Iron Circle Fire is about 160 acres in size and 50% contained. The Caleb Lane Fire is about 50 acres in size with no containment.

* N.C. Forest Service District 10 personnel are responding to the Goinstown Road Fire near the Stokes/Rockingham County line. The fire is about 50 acres in size, 0% contained.

* N.C. Forest Service personnel in Caswell County are responding to the Anderson Road Fire, about 20-30 acres in size and 50% contained.

* As of March 19, 1,040 wildfires have burned on state and private lands statewide since March 1. Ninety-nine percent of wildfires in North Carolina are human-caused which means almost all wildfires are avoidable.

* Burn Ban Notice: Effective 8 a.m. Friday, March 21, a ban on all open burning was issued statewide. All burning permits are canceled. No new permits are being issued.

The ban remains in effect until further notice. Read news release (https://www.ncagr.gov/news/press-releases/2025/03/20/burn-ban-issued-all-north-carolina-counties-due-hazardous-forest-fire-conditions).

Drones and Wildfires: Flying a drone near or over a wildfire is illegal. Don't do it. Firefighting aircraft that respond to wildfires fly low in support of ground personnel. Drones can pose a serious threat to pilot and public safety. A drone that disrupts air operations also puts firefighters, residents and property at risk of loss to wildfire.

To check wildfire activity across the state, use the North Carolina Wildfire Public Viewer at https://ncfspublic.firesponse.com/.

Subscribe to receive updates from the N.C. Forest Service about wildfires, burn bans and other topics at https://public.govdelivery.com/accounts/NCFS/subscriber/new. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htdigital.in

Rebecca Falconer

March 3rd, 2025 ( Axios - Delivered by Newstex )

Firefighters in North and South Carolina were battling dozens of wildfires over the weekend during dry, windy conditions that saw authorities order some residents to evacuate.

The big picture: South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster (R) declared a state of emergency emergency Sunday after officials declared a statewide burn ban the previous day that the governor said would remain in effect indefinitely.

I have declared a State of Emergency to further support wildfire response efforts across the state and ensure our first...

Posted by Henry McMaster on Sunday, March 2, 2025

Evacuation orders were temporarily issued in response to the state's largest blaze, the Carolina Forest Fire, near Myrtle Beach, S.C. - which officials said had razed some 1,600 acres at 30% containment on Sunday evening as residents were permitted to return home.

North Carolina officials also issued evacuation orders in response to a fire in the Blue Ridge Mountains. The 176 Fire had burned over 500 acres by 8pm and was 30% contained Sunday, per a Polk County Emergency Management said on Facebook post that said a decision on lifting evacuation orders would be made Monday.

Zoom out: Strong winds and very dry conditions were promoting "critical to extremely critical fire weather conditions across portions of the Southern Plains, especially across eastern New Mexico and far western Texas" on Sunday, per the National Weather Service.

"As this system initially comes through the Southwest and out into the southern High Plains, there will be concerns for gusty winds, and this coupled with the dry conditions will support elevated to critical fire weather concerns," the NWS said in Sunday forecast discussion.

"Areas of southern Arizona through southern New Mexico and western Texas will see the greatest fire weather concerns through Sunday and early Monday."

urn:contentItem:6G8V-NPR3-RS7D-90TT-00000-00Research on lightweight tunnel cable fire recognition algorithm based on multi-scale features2025-11-15T08:16:05Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisResearch on lightweight tunnel cable fire recognition algorithm based on multi-scale features

Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

Currently, tunnel fire detection faces challenges such as slow response times, high false alarm rates, and poor timeliness. With the rapid development of computer vision, tunnel intelligent fire detection has received extensive attention from academia and industry. In this study, a lightweight YOLO-v5 tunnel cable fire recognition algorithm with multiscale features is proposed. By replacing the YOLO-v5 backbone network, Darknet53, with Mobilenetv3-small and integrating the SimAM attention mechanism, the lightweight and detection speed of the network was improved. Second, under the premise of retaining the feature fusion method of YOLOv5 splicing feature maps by channel, a Bi-directional Feature Pyramid Network (BiFPN) was constructed and the GIou_Loss function was introduced to enhance the network’s target recognition precision. By designing tunnel cable fire experiments under different wind conditions to establish a image standard database, the accuracies and feasibilities of the model are verified. The training results show that the network’s mean Average Precision (mAP 99%) improved by 0.4% and the FPS (179) improved by 46.7% compared to YOLOv5. The approach can meet the needs of tunnel cable fire detection on the precision and the speed. This method provides strong scientific and technological support for the improvement of tunnel Linear fire detection, facilitate the emergency management and therefore significantly contribute to loss prevention.

IntroductionDriven by urbanization and gradual expansion of the urban population, the number and scale of urban traffic tunnels are expanding1, 2–3. However, tunnel structures are characterized by long, narrow, cylindrical, and confined spaces, and traditional tunnel fire detection faces challenges such as slow response times, high false alarm rates, and poor timeliness. Once a fire occurs, the evacuation of people and fire rescue become more difficult, resulting in a large number of casualties and economic losses, as well as a serious negative impact on society4, 5–6.

Image-based fire detection technology has the advantages of being non-contact, responsive, and easy to integrate with existing security monitoring systems. Therefore, it has received particular attention in the field of fire detection. Traditional image recognition7, 8–9 is limited to the overall, static visual characteristics of the flame. Within the monitoring distance, smoke, ambient temperature and humidity, and the emissivity of the object’s surface will affect fire detection, and the false alarm rate is high. Moreover, extracting the flame features takes much effort to eliminate the interference targets, so traditional image fire recognition cannot meet the requirements of real-time fire detection.

In recent years, image-based detection techniques based on deep learning with strong expressive power and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) have been rapidly developed for fire recognition10, 11, 12, 13, 14–15. Aslan et al.16 proposed a vision-based real-time flame detection method using Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Neural Networks (DCGANs), which do not require large amounts of labeled data and consider temporal information. The DCGAN with spatiotemporal flame evolution was trained in two phases and could efficiently detect flames with a very low false alarm rate. Seydi et al.17 designed Fire-Net to detect active fires and burning biomass in Landsat-8 imagery. The framework fuses optical and thermal modalities in images to improve the expressiveness of the model. It employs techniques such as residual and separable convolutional blocks to extract deep features from low-quality datasets. Based on the effectiveness requirements of fire warnings, acomplex network structure causes network training and recognition time overheads. Poor timeliness is a bottleneck that restricts the application of deep learning network recognition to fire images.

To solve the above problems, Iandola et al.18 adopted 1 × 1 convolution instead of 3 × 3 convolution to reduce the number of feature graphs at each layer and achieve a significant reduction in network model parameters. R Girshick et al.19 redesigned the network in view of cardinal number and increased paths number of data flow in the network, this method can improve the detection accuracy of the model without increasing the number of parameters and the amount of computation. Although the proposed algorithm can reduce the complexity of the model to a certain extent, it does not take into account the problems such as the large number of parameters and the loss of target information caused by downsampling, which leads to the decrease of the accuracy of the model.

With the continuous development of computer resources, target recognition networks in deep learning are two-stage detection models [20,21]represented by the R-CNN (Region based Convolutional Neural Network) series and single-stage detection models represented by the YOLO (You Only Look Once) series and SSD (Single Shot Multi box Detector)22,23 which have achieved excellent performance in recognition accuracy and speed.R-CNN and SSD can be used to solve the problem of fire identification in images, but the disadvantage is that these networks can not extract the edge information of the object.

YOLO24, 25, 26–27 with Faster recognition is a mature development that has attracted researchers to explore its potential in fire detection. Deep learning techniques with high precision and efficiency are being rapidly developed for target detection. To improve the performance of detection algorithms, the YOLO series algorithms have been developed to YOLOv8. Although the YOLO series algorithms have developed rapidly, their subsequent algorithms are all improved based on YOLOv5. Compared to YOLOv5, YOLOv8 achieves higher detection accuracy for small targets. However, due to its deeper network structure, the model has a significantly larger number of parameters and requires more computations. As a result, it cannot be deployed on edge devices without GPUs. In the application of target recognition for fire detection, Yar et al.28 used an improved Yolo-v5 model forest for fire detection in smart cities, which is robust to both small and large fires. Niu et al.29 proposed a segmentation model (FF DSM) based on Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) infrared images. Yar et al.30 proposed an improved YOLOv5 architecture using smaller convolutional kernels to replace larger kernels and achieved lightweight fire detection in building fires and indoor electrics. Phan et al.31 proposed an FFS-YOLO-based early fire and smoke detection model for factory fires. The model introduced a SimAM attention mechanism module to highlight fire target features in a shallow network and improve the ability to recognize plant fires. Huang et al.32 proposed a combined intelligent detection and prediction method for tunnel fires with different inclinations, using a Regional Convolutional Neural Network (RCNN) for fire feature extraction and a Residual Network (ResNet) for fire prediction. Currently, deep learning technology is not widely applied in tunnel fire detection, and most studies focus on fire recognition of ignition source rather than line source.

To solve the above problems, in this study, a lightweight YOLO-v5 fire recognition algorithm with multiscale features for tunnel cable fires is proposed. A tunnel cable fire image database was established experimentally, and the original backbone network was replaced by a fusion of a lightweight network and an attention mechanism to improve the detection speed of fire recognition. Simultaneously, the required computational resources are effectively reduced, achieving the dual goals of efficient performance and resource optimization so that it can operate efficiently network’s accuracy in target recognition. Ablation experiments verified the accuracy and feasibility of the model, and scientific and reliable technical support was provided for tunnel cable fire warning and prevention.

Establishment of tunnel cable fire data set

Design of experiments

The tunnel model is designed on a scale of 1:20, with openings at both ends and dimensions of 3 m ×0.26 m ×0.26 m (L×W×H). The interior of the box was composed of an asbestos board with specific thermal insulation properties, and fireproof glass was installed on the side as an observation window, as shown in Fig. 1. A cable bridge (shown in Fig. 2) with a length of 3 m and a width of 0.2 m is placed inside the tunnel. It is divided into two layers, with the lower and upper layers 0.03 m and 0.13 m from the bottom, respectively.

In this experiment, the experimental fire source is the burning pine and the fuel is diesel oil. The ignition source is located 1 m away from the air inlet to allow observation of the combustion process of the cable. To improve ventilation, an axial fan (SFG 3 − 2) is connected with a ventilation pipe with a length of 1 m. In addition, high-speed photography (Sony ILCE-5100 L APS-C) is set 1 m in front of the tunnel model, which is used to record the flame spread speed, flame height, and flame spread trace of cable combustion in the tunnel. According to the national standard JB/T8735.2-2016, the experimental materials are flame-retardant cables (type3 × 2.5) with a diameter of 11 mm, whose sheath is ethylene propylene diene rubber-insulated. Single and double cables with lengths 1 m are selected and built in the bridge frame. Once the cable is ignited, the fire source will be removed. By changing wind speed, the flame structure was recorded by the high-speed photography.

Experimental dataset

In this study, a tunnel cable fire dataset labeled for training was selected to evaluate the performance of the model. During training, four datasets were added to the original dataset via scaling, cropping, rotating, and splicing into a single dataset using the mosaic data enhancement method. The dataset contained nearly 1800 images, randomly divided into training and validation sets in a 7:3 ratio, and labeled as flames. Typical tunnel cable fire images were selected as shown in Fig. 3.

Fig. 3

Experimental data set.

Data processing

In this study, images of the tunnel cable fire experiments in the early and spreading stages of a fire were selected as data samples. The width and height of the flames in the spreading stage were measured using the grey scale threshold method, which resulted in trends in the width and height of the tunnel cable fire over time, as shown in Fig. 4.

YOLO exhibits stretching and translation invariance. The primary method involves dividing the image into S × S grids. Each grid is responsible for detecting the target within the grid. Thus, regardless of how the position of the target changes in the image, it can be detected using the corresponding grid. When the high-speed camera undergoes movement, it is guaranteed that the model can maintain stability and that the recognition algorithm remains effective. It is most suitable for linear fire images of tunnels with telescoping and translational characteristics. Therefore, in this study, the YOLO algorithm is used to identify tunnel cable fires.

Method

Work process

Figure 7 shows the entire work process, which is divided into three parts. The first part is to obtain real-time fire images from a reasonably designed fire experiment and then provide a dataset for YOLO. The second part is the process of suppling these real-time image data to improved YOLO frame by frame for training. The final part, through the comparison between the improved network and other networks, the effect of various improvements in YOLOv5 with an adjusted structure on the tunnel fire detection performance is verified.

Fig. 7

The work process of data extraction.

Network structure design

Improved YOLOv5 network framework

YOLOv5 is a single-stage target-detection algorithm that divides an input image into N×N networks. During training, each network generated three different prediction frames to match the target frames and complete detection. The entire framework needs to be improved to improve the speed and prediction precision of the network training.

In this study, a lightweight multiscale feature YOLO-v5 algorithm for tunnel cable fire recognition is proposed. By adjusting the yolov5 network structure of the target detection model, the model was mainly composed of a Backbone, Neck, and Head, as shown in Fig. 8. The Backbone network adopts a mobilenetv3-small feature extraction network for initial feature extraction and introduces the SimAM mechanism to realize efficient feature enhancement. Neck adopts a bidirectional feature pyramid network (BiFPN), which generates a multiscale feature pyramid by fusion in both the top-down and bottom-up directions to improve the module’s information fusion capability and detection performance. Finally, the Head uses GIoU_Loss as the loss function of the bounding box to detect the target and provide an early warning of a tunnel cable fire.

Fig. 8

Network structure of YOLO v5 with restructured structure.

Backbone network structure design

In this study, the YOLOv5 Backbone was improved to Mobilenetv3 (shown in Fig. 9) to achieve a lightweight network. First, to ensure that the input size of the network was the same, a set of fire images was intercepted from the fire experiment video with 1280 × 720 resolution, which was cropped and converted into a 3D feature matrix of 3 × 640 × 640. The input images are augmented with mosaic data to obtain a rich dataset. Feature extraction uses the Mobilenetv3-small lightweight network, which contains 11 Inverted Residual blocks (shown in Fig. 9), to balance lightweight feature extraction and module hardware perceptibility. The final output is a 3D matrix (96 × 20 × 20) with more advanced features. However, the output per feature map (96 × 20 × 20) has a very large perceptual field, which tends to ignore small object recognition (e.g., small fires). Therefore, a reference-free SimAM attention mechanism is employed at the end of the backbone network to improve the model’s recognition of small objects and its applicability to lightweight devices.

Fig. 9

Inversed residual block.

Neck network design

To fuse the extracted features better, the improved model uses a bidirectional feature pyramid network (BiFPN), as shown in Fig. 10. This method enhances the representation ability of the feature pyramid by introducing two new reverse pathways (bottom-up P3 and top-downpathways P7) and using multiple convolutional layers at each level. While each reverse path uses the technology of skip connection, which can help the BiFPN model better retain information and avoid information loss. It performs feature fusion at different scales from both top-down and bottom-up directions to generate a multiscale feature pyramid and improve the feature fusion capability of the model.

Head network design

YOLOv5 uses the IoU to measure the flame detection accuracy pre-fire, mid-fire, and post-fire (as shown in Fig. 11(a)). The value of Iou was calculated using Eq. (4). To obtain an accurate prediction frame, the head of our model uses GIoU as the loss function of the prediction frame to solve the problem in which the YOLOv5 detection frame and the actual frame cannot overlap.

When there is no overlap, or when the intersection and concurrency ratios of the predicted and actual frames are the same, it is impossible to determine which is more accurate. Therefore, GIoU_Loss introduces a minimum closed shape C (Fig. 11b) to obtain a more accurate prediction box. GIoU_Loss is calculated using Eq. (5).

Model training

Training was conducted using PyTorch as the development framework with an NVIDIA GeForce RTX3050 Laptop GPU, 6GB of video memory, a 12th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-12450 H CPU, and 16GB of RAM. The Adam algorithm was used as the optimizer, and the initial learning rate was 0.01. The learning rate tuning strategy is a one-cycle learning rate. The training batch size of the network is 300epoch, the batch size was four, and the input image size was 640 × 640.

Discussion and analysis

Model evaluation criteria

In this target-detection task, mAP_0.5, Recall, Precision, and FPS were used as the criteria to measure the performance of the model. mAP is the mean average precision used to measure the accuracy and completeness of the model detection results. In general, the mAP value is calculated when IoU = 0.5, that is, mAP_0.5. Where IoU is the intersection ratio, and mAP_0.5 indicates that the average precision of all images of each class in the computational data is calculated when the intersection IoU is 0.5. The mAP was calculated using Eq. (6):

6

where mAP_0.5 denotes the evaluation metric when IoU = 0.5.

Precision is the ratio of the number of correctly predicted flame bounding boxes to all the predicted flame bounding boxes, which reflects the accuracy of the tunnel fire prediction model and is calculated using Eq. (7).

7

Recall is the ratio of the number of correctly predicted flame-enveloping frames to the total number of actual flame-enveloping frames, which reflects the proportion of correctly predicted flame samples and is calculated using Eq. (8).

Ablation experiment results and analysis

Recognition results

In the standard images, there are 2212 images of one and two arrangement of cables under different wind speed conditions simultaneously, including 500 images of windless single-layer cables, 490 images of ventilated single-layer cables, and 1,222 images of ventilated double-layer cables. Furthermore, the training data adopts image flipping and color transformation for data augmentation to avoid the problem of sample imbalance. In this study, a trained network model was used to detect cable fires in tunnels, and the performance of the cable fire detection in different periods, wind speeds, and layers was tested.

Fig. 12

Waveform Diagram of Model Training Results (a)Loss value curves. (b)Accuracy rate curves.

The changes of the loss value and accuracy rate with the number of iterations during the training process are detailed in Fig. 12, the model training shows a good convergence effect. Based on the data in the table, the various evaluation indicators of the model on the test set were calculated. The fire Mean Average Precision rate, recall rate and Accuracy Rate index were 99.0%, 96.40% and 99.5% respectively. Based on these indicators, it can be seen the improved YOLOv5 network for fire identification performs well on the test set and has a good generalization ability.

To verify the predictive validity of the model, the evaluation indicators PCC and significance of Yolov5 network were compared with those of the improved YOLOv5 network. The results are shown in Table 2. It can be seen the correlation coefficient of the improved YOLOv5 network on the test set has increased from 0.913 to 0.937 respectively. It indicates that the improved model features have a stronger linear correlation with the real fire characteristics, and the improved Yolov5 network has achieved significant optimization in feature expression and task adaptability. This is because the structure (MobileNetv3 + SimAM) enhances the discriminability of fire characteristics, and cross-layer connections of BiFPN reduce information loss, and the feature map contains more comprehensive multi-scale fire information, thereby improving the performance of the model.

Fig. 13

Detection diagram of the model.

The results are presented in Fig. 13. It can be observed from the real-world test results that the detection accuracies of the single-layer cable fires were all above 85%. The detection accuracy of single-layer cable fires under windless conditions was more significant than that under windless conditions, reaching more than 90%. This indicates that wind speed reduced the identification precision of the cables. This is mainly because single-layer cable fires are more concentrated and stable under windless conditions, which makes it easier for the model to capture fire features. In contrast, the recognition accuracy of the double-layer cables was greater than that of the single-layer cables at a wind speed of 2.7 m/s. This indicates that the cable structure of the double layer is more complex than that of the single layer, with more flame features and details, which makes the model identification more accurate. However, the real-world fire test results for single- and double-layer cables satisfy the requirements of tunnel fire detection.

Comparative results

To verify the effect of various improvements in YOLOv5 with an adjusted structure on the tunnel fire detection performance, the original algorithm was added to each module separately. Experiments were conducted separately using the same dataset to obtain the corresponding evaluation indices, and the results were analyzed.

Comparison of other SOTA methods

To understand the comparison of the performance of the improved model with other SOTA networks in tunnel fires, representative networks were selected for comparison, namely Faster-RCNN, SSD, DETR and Yolov8 network models. Experiments were conducted using the experimental tunnel cable fire dataset to obtain the training results of each model as shown in Table 3.

It can be seen from Table 3 that the mAP, Recall, and FPS of improved Yolov5 is significantly higher than that of most other methods. Although the mAP of YOLOv8 is higher than that of the improved YOLOv5 network, its FPS is much lower.This is because the four innovations of lightweight backbone network, dynamic attention enhancement, geometric perception loss function and efficient multi-scale fusion have achieved a balance between accuracy and speed. Especially in tunnel scenes, various indicators (mAP, recall and FPS) are significantly superior to other solutions by the robust processing of small targets, which performs slightly better than Faster-RCNN, SSD and DETR algorithm in mAP.

Comparison of different models

To further verify the detection performance of the improved network, five groups were selected for the experiments: YOLOv5 structure, YOLOv5 + Mobilenetv3, YOLOv5 + Mobilenetv3 + SimAM, YOLOv5 + Mobilenetv3 + SimAM + BiFPN, and YOLOv5 + Mobilenetv3 + SimAM + BiFPN + GIoU_Loss. Through the comparison between the improved network and other networks, the effect of various improvements in YOLOv5 with an adjusted structure on the tunnel fire detection performance is verified.

Fig. 14

Bar chart of model performance comparison.

As can be seen in Fig. 14, in terms of detection speed and accuracy, compared to Yolov5, the FPS of the network increases from 122 to 188.2 after using the backbone network MobileNetv3-small, which is an improvement of 54.3%, but the accuracy decreases. On the other hand, the introduction of the SimAM attention mechanism supplements the loss of accuracy due to the lightweight network structure to a certain extent, but reduces the network’s speed. Introducing a bidirectional feature pyramid network (BiFPN) improved the precision by 0.1%, and the detection precision reached 99%. By introducing the YOLOv5 network with a loss function (GIoU_Loss), the FPS increased by 5.9% with guaranteed accuracy. The inference speed of the restructured YOLOv5 network reached 179 FPS, which is a 46.7% improvement over YOLOv5. The mAP was improved by 0.4(%), but the recall was only reduced by 0.4(%). The adjusted structure of YOLOv5 has a breakneck inference speed and high detection accuracy for tunnel cable fire detection while meeting the requirement of a low false detection rate, thereby realizing a good balance between performance and efficiency.

Comparison of various attention mechanisms

To increase the effectiveness of recognizing tunnel cable fires in small tunnels, the improved target detection algorithm (YOLOv5-MobileNetv3 + SimAM) in this study was compared with the target recognition results of the different attention mechanisms SE, Convolutional Block Attention Module(CBAM), and CA. As shown in Fig. 15, the mAP, Recall, and FPS of the SimAM mechanism were 98.9%, 96.8%, and 172.4, respectively. In terms of inference speed, compared to coordinate attention (CA), squeeze-and-excitation (SE) and convolutional block attention module (CBAM) mechanisms have been substantially improved. This shows that the SimAM attention mechanism can improve the accuracy and has a small number of parameters and a small amount of computation.

Fig. 15

Comparison of Attention Mechanism Modules.

Comparison of different loss functions

The bounding box regression loss function GIoU was introduced into YOLOv5 of the adjusted structure for framing tunnel cable fires. As shown in Fig. 16, the mAP_0.5 and FPS of the bounding box regression GIoU loss module were much higher than those of the IoU, CIoU, and DIoU bounding box regression loss modules, and the recall was slightly lower. The mAP_0.5, Recall, and FPS were 99%, 96.4%, and 179, respectively. Therefore, the predictive performance of the model can be improved by the GIoU bounding box regression loss module, especially with regard to the inference speed.

Fig. 16

Comparison of the Bounding Box Regression Loss Modules.

Comparison of optimizers

Two sets of comparative experiments were designed. The experimental results of our model were compared using the SGD and Adam optimization algorithms, as shown in Fig. 17.

Fig. 17

Comparison between SGD optimization algorithm and Adam optimization algorithm.

As shown in Fig. 17 that the model’s mAP_0.5, Recall, and FPS of the model were higher when the Adam optimization algorithm was used than when the SGD optimization algorithm was used. Therefore, the adjusted YOLOv5 model finally adopted the Adam optimization algorithm, with a MAP of up to 99%, recall of up to 96.4%, and FPS of up to 179. The reasoning speed is extremely high, and the false detection rate is low, which meets the requirements of tunnel fire detection accuracy.

Recognition of single and double-layer cable fires with different wind speeds

In the training phase of the network model proposed in this study, Fig. 18 shows the convergence process of Precision, Recall, and mAP_0.5 during the training process of the tunnel fire detection model for windless single-layer cables, single- and double-layer cable fire data with a wind speed of 2.7 m/s, and all cable fire datasets. The number of training rounds was 300, which reflects the rapid convergence of the model.

Figure 18 shows the convergence process graphs of the recognition precision, recall, and mAP for the single- and double-layer cables under different wind speeds, which reached a stably high value after 200 epochs. As shown in Fig. 18(a), the highest recognition precision of 99.1% is achieved for cables under no-wind conditions. At a wind speed of 2.7 m/s, the recognition accuracies of the single- and double-layer cables were lower than those of the wind-free condition, which were 97.8% and 98.2%, respectively. This is mainly due to the fact that the identification of tunnel cable fires is affected by the complexity of the scene, and the more complex the environment, the lower the accuracy. However, the accuracy of the single- and double-layer tunnel fires reached 97.2%, which meets the requirements for tunnel fire detection.

Figure 18(b) shows that the highest recall rate of 99.2% was observed for cables under windless conditions. With a wind speed of 2.7 m/s, the recall rate of the double-layer cable was lower than that of the single-layer cable by 98% and 95.4%. This is mainly because the lower cable in the double-layer cable is blocked by the upper cable, which causes the flame to be blocked at certain angles, thereby affecting the recall rate of flame detection in the double-layer cable. However, the recall rate of the single- and double-layer tunnel fires was 96.4%, which meets the requirements for tunnel fire detection.

Figure 18(c) shows that the mAP of the cable under windless conditions is the highest at 99.5%. At a wind speed of 2.7 m/s, the mAP of the single- and double-layer cables was lower than that of the wind-free condition by 98.7% and 98.4%, respectively. This is mainly because the generalization ability of the model in wind conditions cannot adapt well to new conditions. Secondly, wind affects the ambient light intensity and brightness around the flame, which affects the quality of the flame image and makes it challenging to capture the contours and features of the flame, thereby decreasing the mAP value. At a wind speed of 2.7 m/s, the mAP of double-layer cables was lower than that of single-layer cables, which was mainly affected by the structural complexity and shading effect. However, the mAP of the single- and double-layer tunnel fires reached 99%, which satisfied the requirements for tunnel fire detection.

Fig. 18

Convergence process of evaluation indexes for single and double-layer cable(a) Convergence process graph of precision for single- and double-layer cables. (b) Convergence process graph of recall for single- and double-layer cables. (c) Convergence process graph of mAP for single- and double-layer cable.

Figure 19 shows the mapping relationship between the fire recognition precision and recall during training. The larger the area enclosed by the PR on the X- and Y-axes, the higher the detection performance of the network model. Notably, the recall of linear tunnel cable fires maintained the accuracy of this network model above 0.95, even when it was higher than 0.9. This indicates that effective control of false alarms is maintained when performing linear tunnel fire identification, thus ensuring sufficient response time in an emergency.

Fig. 19

PR curve diagram for single and double-layer cable.

To test the robustness of the single- and double-layer cable fire recognition, some interference term images were added. Additional flame information can be included in a single image by splicing several different images. Fire detection was performed using this model and the results are shown in Fig. 20.

As shown in Fig. 20, after the dataset was scaled, cropped, rotated, and spliced, the network properly recognized the fire. Therefore, the model was adapted to complex scenarios and variations. Mosaic data augmentation not only improves the robustness of the model but also reduces the occurrence of overfitting.

Fig. 20

Fire disturbance identification(a) Identification of fire disturbances in single-layer cables at wind speed of 0 m/s. (b) Identification of fire disturbances in single-layer cables at a wind speed of 2.7 m/s.(c) Identification of fire interference in double-layer cables at a wind speed of 2.7 m/s.

Conclusions and future work

In this study, a tunnel cable fire database was established, and a lightweight multiscale YOLO-v5 tunnel cable fire identification algorithm was proposed to verify the accuracy and feasibility of the proposed model. The main conclusions are summarized as follows:

Experiments on tunnel cable fires under different wind speed and different quantities were conducted, and a high-definition fire image standard database for the basic research of tunnel cable fire detection were established.

By replacing the YOLO-v5 Backbone network with Mobilenetv3-small, the SimAM attention mechanism was fused to realize a lightweight network to improve the detection speed of the network. Second, under the premise of retaining the feature fusion method of YOLOv5 and splicing the feature maps by channel, a bidirectional feature pyramid network (BiFPN) is constructed, along with the GIoU_Loss loss function, which in turn enhances the network’s target recognition accuracy. The model evaluation metric obtained on the self-constructed tunnel cable dataset compared to the mAP was 99 (%), which was 0.4 (%) higher than that of YOLOv5. The mean FPS score was 179, which is 46.7% higher. Recall was 96.4 (%), only 0.4 (%) lower than that of YOLOv5.

A comparison of the improved algorithm between single- and double-layer tunnel cables with different wind speeds showed that the windless single-layer cable had the highest recognition mAP of 99.5% and a recall of 99.2%. At a wind speed of 2.7 m/s, the single- and double-layer cables were lower than the mAP of the windless condition by 98.7% and 98.4%, respectively. The recall rates were also lower than 98% and 95.4% for the windless conditions, respectively.

The proposed approach is developed for practical application in high-fire-risk industries, where electrical cables is the leading cause of line fires. Its industrial deployment will help detect fire at the very early stage, facilitate the emergency management and therefore significantly contribute to loss prevention.

urn:contentItem:6FFP-HTT3-S8XR-N3W4-00000-00Opinion: The fate of our future - how climate change shapes the lives of young Utahns2025-03-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENT NEWS & CLIMATE CHANGE NEWSOpinion: The fate of our future - how climate change shapes the lives of young UtahnsRegan Fillmore

Kristin Murphy

Dried lake bed is pictured in Farmington Bay, looking at Antelope Island, as the Great Salt Lake experiences record low water levels on Friday, July 22, 2022.

1

Growing up in Idaho, I always dreamed of moving to Utah. The mountains, the red rocks and the lively outdoor culture felt like the perfect place to build my future. I've now been a Utah resident for four years and I have found many reasons to love Utah, but I've also seen firsthand how climate change is threatening the very landscapes that drew me here in the first place. It's changing the way I think about my future, the choices I make and whether Utah will be a place where I can stay long-term.

Utah is getting hotter, fast. Between 1970 and 2023, fall temperatures in Utah's Weber and Davis counties rose by 4.5°F, with nearly all counties experiencing at least a 3°F increase. Salt Lake City recorded its hottest October on record in 2024, averaging 66.2°F - almost 10 degrees above normal. The heat of the summer is uncomfortable and long for residents, but the real cost is the lengthy forest fire season that increases respiratory issues for people like me who love spending time outdoors. Not only do the grey skies prevent me from spending time outside, but the dreary scenery is also a heavy mental reminder that our world is drastically changing.

The Great Salt Lake is a defining feature of Utah's ecosystem and has experienced significant fluctuations in its surface area. In 1986, the lake covered approximately 2,300 square miles, but by July 2022, it had shrunk to a historic low elevation. This isn't just an environmental crisis - it's a public health risk. As the lakebed dries up, it releases toxic dust into the air, increasing risks of respiratory diseases.

History has shown us how important the Great Salt Lake is, and my fear is that we are denying the facts and selfishly using our resources. If Utah can't manage its water resources effectively, I have to ask myself: is this a place where I can build a long-term future?

It is hard to ignore how daily life has been affected. Since 1970, the demand for cooling in Salt Lake City schools has surged by 55%. Schools are having to spend more on air conditioning, and students are struggling to focus in overheated classrooms. As Utah grows, so does the strain on infrastructure - not just in education, but in housing, energy and transportation.

Young people are incredibly aware of this issue, and we're fighting back. In 2022, a group of youth activists filed a lawsuit against the state, arguing that its push for fossil fuel development violates their right to a healthy environment. This case highlights a larger truth: my generation isn't waiting for politicians to take action. We're demanding it.

When I first moved to Utah, I imagined it as my forever home. But climate change is forcing me to reconsider. Do I stay and fight for policies that will protect the environment I love, or do I eventually leave for a place with fewer climate risks? These are the kinds of questions young Utahns like me are grappling with, not decades from now, but today.

A call to action

Utah's leaders need to face reality. We need policies that prioritize sustainable water management, renewable energy investments and stricter environmental protections. This isn't about politics - it's about making sure Utah remains a livable, thriving place for future generations.

I moved here because I believed in Utah's future. Now, I'm doing everything I can to make sure it still has one.

urn:contentItem:6F6N-NDX3-RVV5-91W9-00000-00Study Results from Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Update Understanding of Photogrammetric Engineering Remote Sensing (Spatiotemporal Behavior of Active Forest Fires Using Time-series Modis C6 Data)2025-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisENGINEERING - PHOTOGRAMMETRIC ENGINEERING REMOTE SENSINGStudy Results from Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Update Understanding of Photogrammetric Engineering Remote Sensing (Spatiotemporal Behavior of Active Forest Fires Using Time-series Modis C6 Data)


2025 FEB 25 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Engineering Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in Engineering - Photogrammetric Engineering Remote Sensing. According to news originating from Telangana, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forestfires have a profound influence on the economy, ecology, and environment. Realizing the potential of remote sensing in forest fire management, a study was taken up to investigate the spatiotemporal behavior of active forest fires in a mountainous terrain of Uttarakhand State, north India, using 15 years'time-series historical MODIS (C6) active fire point products."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, "Results indicate an overall fire incidence detection accuracy of 62.3% with a KHAT value of 0.59. Moreover, a regular trend in intra-annual behavior in fire incidences with peaks during the hot and dry period of the year was observed and a large year-to-year variability in fire regimes with no significant trends over time could be noticed."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The approach and results are discussed in detail along with the future perspective."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Spatiotemporal Behavior of Active Forest Fires Using Time-series Modis C6 Data. Photogrammetric Engineering & Remote Sensing, 2025;91(2):85-90. Photogrammetric Engineering & Remote Sensing can be contacted at: Amer Soc Photogrammetry, 5410 Grosvenor Lane Suite 210, Bethesda, MD 20814-2160, USA.
The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from R. S. Dwivedi, Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad 500085, Telangana, India.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.14358/pers.24-00035r2. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Telangana, India, Asia, Photogrammetric Engineering Remote Sensing, Engineering, Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University.

urn:contentItem:6DP5-9883-S00V-62CK-00000-00PARLIAMENT QUESTION:- CONSERVATION OF FOREST2024-12-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisPARLIAMENT QUESTION:- CONSERVATION OF FORESTStates News ServiceNEW DELHI, India

The following information was released by the Government of India:

by PIB Delhi

There are legal frameworks for the protection and management of forest and wildlife resources of the country which include, Indian Forest Act 1927, Van (Sanrakshan Evam Samvardhan) Adhiniyam 1980, Wildlife (Protection) Act 1972 and the State Forest Acts, Tree Preservation Acts and Rules, etc,. Protection and management of forest and wildlife is primarily the responsibility of the State Governments/Union Territory Administrations.The State Governments /UT Administrations take appropriate actions to protect forests and wildliferesources under the provisions made under these Acts/ Rules.

As per the existing provisions of Van (Sanrakshan Evam Samvardhan) Adhiniyam, 1980, State Governments and Union Territory Administrations are required to ensure that, least number of trees are felled for developmental projects whilst prescribing necessary compensatory plantation as per the cases to address environmental concerns.

The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has formulated a National Action Plan on Forest Fire-2018, which provides comprehensive measures to prevent forest fires, to improve the resilience of the forests against fire hazards, besides prescribing measures such as capacity building of communities in prevention and control of forest fire.

The Ministry has issued advisories to all States/UTs for better management of situations arising out of human-animal conflicts. The advisories recommend various measures that may be adopted by States / UTs to prevent and manage such conflicts. These include coordinated interdepartmental action, identification of conflict hot spots, and adherence to Standard Operating Procedures, establishment of rapid response teams, provision of adequate funds for payment of ex-gratia relief to affected persons in case of human death and injury, etc,.

In consonance with the National Forest Policy 1988, emphasizing the local community based approach, the concept of Joint Forest Management was launched and Joint Forest Management Committees (JFMCs) were formed in States/UTs. Local Communities are involved through Joint Forest Management Committees in the management of forests and in various forestry activities. Further, for the management of the Protected Areas, Eco Development Committees (EDCs) are also formed to ensure people participation in wildlife protection and conservation.

The Ministry supports the targeted efforts of the States/ UTs in the conservation and protection of forests and wildlife, through its ongoing Centrally Sponsored Schemes (CSSs) such as Forest Fire Prevention and Management, Green India Mission, Nagar Van Yojana, Development of Wildlife Habitat (DWH), Project Elephant and Tiger, as well as through the CAMPA funds, Scheme on Mangrove initiative forShoreline Habitats and Tangible Incomes (MISHTI),etc,. The Ministry sanctions the scheme-specific activities through the Annual Plan of Operations submitted by States/ UTs for the respective financial years.

The Ministry has released Indian Forest Management Standard as a part of National Working Plan Code 2023. This standard is a basis for monitoring of sustainable forest management in terms of a broad framework comprising criteria, indicators and verifiers which provides the platform for Indian Forest and Wood Certification Scheme to address the challenges of small scale timber producers.

The Forest Survey of India (FSI), Dehradun, an organization under the Ministry has been carrying out the assessment of forest cover of the country, biennially since 1987, and the findings are published in India State of Forest Report (ISFR). As per latest ISFR 2021, the total forest cover of the country is 7,13,789 square kilometres which is 21.71% of the geographical areaof the country. The trend for the last three ISFRs shows an increase in forest cover of the country. The forest cover increased by 1,540 square kilometres between ISFR 2019 and ISFR 2021 assessment reports.

The Ek Ped Maa Ke Naam campaign launched by the Honble Prime Minister on 5th June, 2024 draws a parallel between the nurturing of nature by Mother Earth, and the nurturing of human lives by our mothers. It aims to underline this relation by voluntary planting of trees as a mark of love, respect and honour for mothers and by pledging to protect trees and mother earth by all citizens.

This information was given by Union Minister of State for Environment, Forest and Climate Change Shri Kirti Vardhan Singh in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today.

urn:contentItem:6F3S-NJ23-RS4M-13SN-00000-00Pelicans' brass doubling down on Zion Williamson's upside2025-02-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:05ZLexisNexisSPORTS NEWSPelicans' brass doubling down on Zion Williamson's upsideBRETT MARTELAP Sports WriterMETAIRIE, La.

METAIRIE, La. (AP) — The New Orleans Pelicans are doubling down on injury-plagued, sixth-year pro Zion Williamson, hoping he can be a more reliable and productive centerpiece in the years to come.

If that wasn't clear when the Pelicans (12-41) chose to trade high-scoring wing Brandon Ingram to Toronto — and keep Williamson — before last week's NBA trade deadline, Pelicans basketball operations chief David Griffin left no doubt about it in his first meeting with reporters since the move on Tuesday.

“If you take just his body of work this year, what he’s done for us when he’s been healthy, he’s taking steps every day and he’s grown by leaps and bounds, both on the court and off,” Griffin said. “The player he is now is better than he’s ever been.”

The potential for Williamson's rare combination of raw athletic ability, explosiveness and size (listed at 6-foot-6, 284 pounds) to translate in the NBA has been evident since his first few games on the court back in late January 2020 — after the first of what has become several long injury absences.

This season, Williamson has averaged 23.9 points, 7.3 rebounds and 4.9 assists in 17 games. He's also missed 36 games, primarily because of a hamstring injury.

Key questions surrounding Williamson — who is under contract for three more seasons — have centered on his health, maturity and even his commitment to his profession. At times, he has struggled with his weight and conditioning. During the 2023 offseason, there were unsavory and very public social media posts by a spurned romantic partner. This season, he was suspended one game for being late for a team flight.

Along the way, Williamson, who is slated to suit up against Sacramento on Wednesday night, has missed 243 of 444 regular-season games since being drafted first overall out of Duke in 2019.

“Zion has dealt with a great number of challenges, some of which were sort of his own doing, quite frankly," Griffin said. “And he would tell you that.”

But Griffin expressed confidence that the Williamson of the present and near future — in terms of maturity, reliability and availability — won't resemble the seemingly star-crossed player he has been for most of the past six seasons.

“People mature at different rates in the league, and sometimes that maturity looks like a brushfire and sometimes it looks like a forest fire," Griffin said. "I think he’s reaching forest-fire status now — and that’s exciting.

“From a leadership perspective,” Griffin added, Williamson is “doing things he’s never done before, and he’s much more vocal than he’s ever been. ... He’s embracing the opportunity he has to seize this team."

Griffin also defended the Pelicans' medical team in the face of an unprecedented rash of injuries that have kept all five starters out for extended periods.

"These things that happened in most cases were completely flukish and unavoidable,” Griffin said.

Ingram (ankle) played in just 18 of 51 games before he was traded.

Top defensive player Herb Jones (shoulder) has played in just 20 games this season and Griffin said Tuesday he'll probably be “shut down for the season here soon."

Dejounte Murray, a top offseason acquisition, missed several weeks after breaking his hand in his first game with New Orleans. After he returned, he played just 30 more games before an Achilles tear ended his season.

CJ McCollum, who missed 14 games early this season because of an adductor injury, has looked like a relative pillar of health.

“It’s been almost an unimaginable cascade effect of things that have happened to us this year,” Griffin said, noting that the Pelicans have had 29 different starting lineups.

“We need to get better just in terms of our ability to build a more available roster," Griffin said. “Obviously, that’s something we’ve failed at to this point.”

Griffin said the Pelicans harbored high hopes for Williamson and Ingram as a tandem. But Griffin noted that they played just 34% of their games as Pelicans together during the past five-plus seasons — an untenable trend for the two highest-paid players on the team.

"We reached a point where financially we weren’t going to be able to keep the group together as we were constructed,” Griffin said.

The Ingram trade brought the Pelicans two established veterans in Bruce Brown and Kelly Olynyk, who will be relied upon to help New Orleans' relatively young roster mature professionally.

While Brown's contract is expiring and Olynyk has one more season left on his, Griffin said, “This is not viewed as a short-term situation with either player in our minds.

"We hope, as the season unfolds, they grow to feel the same about us,” Griffin said.

___
